Graphical abstract The influence of Nuclear Quantum Effects (NQEs) on electronic properties of high-performance Pt/dCNC catalysts for hydrogen storage applications for the future development on the spillover mechanism We investigated H-spillover mechanisms on Pt atoms decorating defective carbon nanocones (Pt/dCNC) using the multicomponent B3LYP (MC_B3LYP) method, which can take account of the nuclear quantum effect (NQE) of light nuclei. MC_B3LYP shows reduced relative energies for all stationary-point structures and lower energy barriers to H-spillover reactions. Interestingly, MC_B3LYP calculations reveal that the activation energy for H2 dissociation completely vanishes indicating that H2 molecules dissociate readily on Pt/dCNC. Our crucial finding is that the different metal (Pt and Pd) on dCNC surface has affected the thermodynamic favorability of the hydrogen dissociation process, on Pt/dCNC is facile and highly exothermic, while on Pd/dCNC is dramatically endothermic. Furthermore, comparison of combined dissociation-spillover mechanism on Pt decorated on carbon nanocone (Pt/dCNC) and Pt decorated on graphene (Pt/dG) catalysts have been focused to explain the curvature effect which can facilitate the hydrogen spillover process and provide a highly exothermic reaction, which is more thermodynamically favorable than that of a metal-graphene surface. Our new understanding of this reaction mechanism and the influence of NQEs on electronic properties will be useful for the future development of the spillover mechanism as well as the synthesis of high-performance Pt/dCNC for H2 energy applications. Keywords DFT Hydrogen spillover Hydrogen storage Carbon nanocone Nuclear quantum effect (NQE) H/D isotope effect 1 Introduction Our investment in energy derived from fossil fuel, renewable energy, and alternative energy sources receives considerable research attention [1–3]. Hydrogen gas (H2) is an ideal energy carrier. It is a cost-effective, non-polluting, and the source of sustainable energy, and it provides a viable alternative to fossil fuels [4–7]. The most crucial challenge faced by materials scientists is H2 storage [8,9]. Hydrogen gas can be produced by chemical reaction, which then can be stored in either liquid or gaseous forms [10], for instance, liquid-hydrogen storage, solid-state conformable storage, and compressed fuel storage [11]. Using compressed fuel cylinders for hydrogen storage requires very high-pressures, heavy machinery, and offers low storage efficiency. Numerous carbon allotropes are suitable for hydrogen storage applications due to their lightweight and inexpensive, with desirable hydrogen-adsorption and desorption energies, and chemically stable. Nevertheless, pristine carbon-based nanomaterials are chemically inert and not suited for hydrogen adsorption. Constructing defects by doping with hetero-atoms can effectively modify these carbon based-nanostructures for H2 storage. Transition-metal [12–15] or light alkali and alkaline earth metal doping [16–18] provide significant improvements in the physical and electronic structure of neighboring carbon atoms and provide active sites for hydrogen molecule capture. Carbon nanocones (CNC), sometimes called carbon nanohorns (CNH) [19–21], are a carbon-based nanomaterial with a structure akin to that of rolled-up graphene. Their greater curvature offers unique chemical reactivity. CNHs have a key advantage over single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) is the controlling of nanowindows opening at either tips or sidewalls of CNHs. Moreover, the CNHs showed the absence of metal catalyst during synthesis and provided a high yield and production rate. Remarkably, the direct functionalization on CNHs is higher than that it is SWCNTs or graphene, indicating more chemical reactivity for CNHs [19]. CNHs were first observed experimentally during an arc-evaporation experiment in 1994, and arc-discharge methods now provide a low-cost synthesis of CNH [22]. Unfortunately, the research of CNHs have been slowed by many factors such as the process of synthesis, the aggregation of CNC into “dahlia-like” clusters ∼100 nm in diameter, the lack of treatment and functionalization of individual nanocones. Nowadays, a new method to separating CNHs clusters into individual nanocones has been successfully investigated. Therefore, Karousis et al. reviewed the synthesis, structure, and topology of CNH, including its chemistry and applications [19]. They reported that CNC materials are a novel carbon allotrope with many potential applications [23–30], mainly as a substrate for hydrogen storage [28,31–38]. The comparison of hydrogen storage on carbon-based nanomaterials, W.-C. Xu et al. revealed that the hydrogen storage performance of SWCNHs is higher than that of graphitic carbon nanofibers (CNFs) and SWCNTs [39]. The H-spillover process enhances the capacity of hydrogen storage [40–45] on an adsorbent support [46–49]. H spillover involves two main steps; First, a hydrogen molecule adsorbs to a transition metal atom such as Pt or Pd, located on a local carbon supporting atom. Second, the hydrogen molecule dissociates to form two metal-hydride moieties, which then migrate to the substrate. Theoretical studies of H-spillover on numerous graphene substrates reveal that these are highly endothermic reactions. Consequently, the migration of dissociated hydrogen atoms to the substrate is thermodynamically unfavorable and hinders the storage of hydrogen. Recently, researchers reported exothermic H-atom migration reactions at Pt supported on defective carbon nanohorns [50,51]. Liu et al. [28]. studied the hydrogen dissociation at a metal atom and the consequent spillover of hydrogen atom onto CNC by making inelastic neutron scattering measurements. Moreover, Sano and coworkers [31] synthesized Pd − Ni alloy nanoparticles on single- wall CNHs (Pd − Ni/SWCNHs) to find that sizeable hydrogen storage capacity on Pd − Ni/SWCNHs occurs via the spillover pathway. Hydrogen dissociation and spillover are crucial processes for enhanced hydrogen storage, but the details require further clarification. Nuclear quantum effects (NQEs) of hydrogen and deuteron nuclei, also called the H/D isotope effect, have attracted interest because of their importance in various interesting chemical, physical, and biological phenomena [52]. Moreover, NQEs occur in the functional expression of biological macromolecules, such as proteins, which undergo low-energy barrier hydrogen-bonded (LBHB) interactions; Additionally, hydrogen nuclei NQEs are implicated in hydrogen transfer reactions [53–58]. We propose a multicomponent quantum mechanical (MC_QM) method to account for the hydrogen NQEs directly. Recently, we studied the importance of the hydrogen nucleus NQE in several hydrogen transfer reactions [59–62] using the MC_QM-climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method, to reveal that NQE significantly lowers the energy barrier for the reactions of hydrogen transfer. Deuterium has twice the mass of the 1H isotope; these are the only two stable isotopes of hydrogen. Replacing hydrogen with deuterium often induces important the eﬀ ;ects of hydrogen/deuterium (H/D) isotope. For example, solvent H/D isotope effects (deuterium substitution of solvent molecules) are crucial for chemical reactions that occur in solution. The critical temperature of the γB-crystallin lens protein in D2O is 16 K higher than it is in H2O [63]. Sugiura reported the H/D isotope effect on hydrogen transfer reactions of the type: Cl + (H2O)n (n = 1–3) [60]. Deuterium substitution of a hydrogen-bonded hydrogen atom has a significant impact on the phase transition temperature of hydrogen-bonded ferroelectric material (>100 K) [64]. In the hydrogen transfer reaction of 1,5sigmatropic in 1,3-pentadiene, the rate constant for transfer of a proton is more than ten times greater than that for deuterium transfer [65]. In this report, we applied our advanced MC_DFT method to investigate the reaction of H2 dissociation and H-spillover over Pt-decorated defective carbon nanocones (Pt/dCNC), while taking NQE of the hydrogen nucleus into account as discuss in details of the theory in S1. We also reveal H/D isotope effects on geometry and reaction energy profiles by applying the MC_DFT method. Additionally, we compare the reactions on Pt/dCNC to the platinum decoration on defective graphene (Pt/dG). 2 Computational methodology All DFT calculations were investigated using the Gaussian 16 software program [66]. We optimized geometries for all structures and performed frequency calculations by performing Becke’s three-parameter hybrid exchange-correlation functional (B3LYP) [67–70]. The 6−31G(d,p) basis set is used for all atoms, and LANL2DZ basis set for the Pt atom. Then, we calculated energies of all structures by simulating single point calculation using the B3LYP functional, including Grimme’s D3 dispersion correction (B3LYP-D3) [71] with the 6−311 G (d,p) [70] and the cc-pVTZ-PP [72,73]. All structures were calculated for the singlet state because the model single state have greater stability than the high-spin state, as explained in our previous work [74]. We constructed carbon nanocone structures by defining the pentagonal rings at the cone tip [19,75]. In this work, we represent the model by a cone with four pentagonal rings and hydrogen termination at the cone edge [50]. Defective Pt/dCNC substrate were modeled by replacing one carbon atom in the tip with a Pt atom. We explained the stability of the Pt atom on the dCNC support by using Eq (1): (1) E bind = E Pt/dCNC −E Pt – E dCNC here E Pt/dCNC, E Pt, and E dCNC correspond to the total energies of Pt/dCNC, the Pt atom, and the dCNC substrate, respectively. We calculated the hydrogen-adsorption energy (E ads) on Pt/dCNC by performing Eq (2): (2) E ads = E H2-Pt/dCNC − E H2---Pt/dCNC where, E H2-Pt/dCNC and E H2---Pt/dCNC, represent to total energies of adsorbed H2 on Pt/dCNC and the farthest H2 adsorption on Pt/dCNC, respectively. The farthest H2 adsorption over Pt/dCNC is found by extending the distance between the H2 and Pt/dCNC to a point where there is no observable interaction between them. To describe the reaction pathway conformations for our proposed mechanism on Pt/dCNC, we calculated intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) from transition state to local minima (reactants, intermediates, and products). To confirm the transition state of each step, only one imaginary vibrational frequency is found in frequency calculations. To find the effective TS structure, we used MC_B3LYP-CI-NEB on the potential energy surface (PES) [61]. The activation energy (E a) is calculated as: (3) E a = E TS - E reactant where, E TS and E reactant correspond to the energies of the TS and the prior reactant, respectively, before the formation of the TS. We modified version of the GAUSSIAN 16 software program to perform MC_B3LYP calculations. Additionally, we calculated CI-NEB by using a homemade program [61]. Details of the multicomponent density functional theory (MC_DFT) method are in supporting information S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reaction mechanism over the Pt atom on dCNC We investigated the optimized geometries of Pt atoms decorating the various cone layers (S2) to optimize the structure for a Pt-atom-decorated single vacancy in CNC-2L (Fig. 1 ). To identify a suitable cluster for the reaction, we established a reaction mechanism for H2 storage on a Pt atom, decorating different cone layers for two basic steps, (i.) H2 adsorption and (ii.) H-spillover, including H2 dissociation into H atoms and migration of the atomic hydrogen atoms from the metal to the support. We describe these two elementary reaction mechanisms below. There are two disparate modes of H2 adsorption for a carbon-based-nanomaterial supported metal atom. These are (i) Kubas mode (or K-mode), non-dissociative H2 adsorption [76], and (i) D-mode, a dissociated dihydride adsorption [77]. H2 adsorption to Pt on CNC is stable for both K- and D-mode, as reported by Rungnim and coworkers [51]. To clarify the effect of the cone layer, we investigated the hydrogen-adsorption properties on three different cone layers (Table S2). The hydrogen-adsorption energies for K-mode on Pt/dCNC-2L, dCNC-3L, and dCNC-4L are -0.46, -0.43, and 0.44 eV, respectively, and these results correspond to literature values [50,51]. We conclude that neither structural nor electronic properties of the clusters show any significant changes. Hydrogen spillover is a crucial mechanism for both efﬁcient hydrogen storage and heterogeneous catalysis [78–82]. The process comprises three primary steps: (i) K-mode adsorption; chemisorption of gaseous hydrogen molecules on a metal catalyst, (ii) dissociation of adsorbed H2 into H atoms to form metal dihydrides on the metal catalyst; and (iii) migration of H atoms from the metal catalyst to the substrate surface and their subsequent diffusion within the substrate. Herein, we investigate hydrogen spillover on a Pt-atom supported on three different cone layers, and focus only on the H2 dissociation mechanism and the first H-atom spillover from Pt to the CNC surface (Fig. 2 ). Fig. 2 shows both K- and D-mode hydrogen adsorption, and the related transition states in the stepwise H-spillover reaction mechanism. The initial configuration is the K-mode non-dissociative chemisorption. The 1st and 2nd transition states are TS1-H2-disso and TS2-H-spillover. The sequence intermediates are FS1-H2-disso (D-mode) and FS2-H-spillover. For Pt/dCNC-2L, the reaction starts with dissociation of molecular hydrogen into D-mode, with an energy barrier of 0.06 eV, while the activation energies for both 3L and 4L are 0.08 eV. Thus, gaseous H2 easily dissociates over Pt on the CNC material. Comparing the hydrogen dissociation step with literature results, H2 dissociation is barely possible over Pt/dG (0.29 eV) [74], Cu-dG (1.31 eV) [83] and CoN3dG (0.95 eV) [84]. H-spillover begins with the dissociation of adsorbed H2. The first hydrogen atom then migrates from Pt to a neighboring surface carbon. In a previous study, we reported that the first hydrogen atom transfers from the Pt atom to the C1 carbon in preference to other carbon atom destinations, and so we selected the H1 to C1 migration pathway. The activation energies for preferable H-spillover routes for 2L, 3L, and 4L are estimated to be 0.76, 0.74, and 0.76 eV, respectively. Figure S2 clearly shows the structural properties of these species. To provide an understanding of the H-spillover mechanism, we discuss the reaction on the 2 L material in detail. At the TS2-H-spillover stage on 2L, the H1 atom preferentially locates between the H2 and C1 atoms. The H1-H2 bond distance is approximately 2.887 Å, longer than that for the FS1-H2-Disso intermediate that occurs during dissociative adsorption. The H1 atom closely approaches C1 in the cone, which provides the shortest migration route, before bonding to C1, with a C1-H1 bond length of 1.105 Å. In a concerted step, H2 approaches the Pt atom, closing the distance from 1.651 to 1.635 Å on the formation of the Pt-H2 bond. Theoretical PES for this reaction show that H spillover on the metal-graphene composite is endothermic [85–87]. By contrast, for the Pt/dCNC system, featuring three different cone layers, our obtained hydrogen spillover process is highly exothermic and is thermodynamically favorable. From this comparison, we see that the structural and electronic properties and the potential energy profiles of the three different cone layers are not significantly different. In consequence, we attempted to use the Pt/dCNC-2 L model for more detailed MC_DFT calculations (Fig. 3 ). 3.2 Investigation of H2/D2 adsorption, combined H2/D2 -dissociation and H/D-spillover on Pt/dCNC-2 L using MC_DFT 3.2.1 H2 and D2 adsorption We compared the hydrogen and deuterium adsorption properties. Fig. 4 shows optimized geometries for H2 and D2 adsorption obtained by MC_DFT. Compared to conventional DFT, the MC_DFT(H) and MC_DFT(D) methods give longer bonds for adsorbed H2 and D2. Table 1 shows geometrical parameters for the optimized H2 adsorption structure. The H-Pt distance and D-Pt distances are shorter than those found using conventional DFT because of the longer HH bond found using MC_DFT. Standard DFT predicts the hydrogen-adsorption energy to be -0.46 eV. However, MC_DFT provides more negative values at -0.58 and -0.54 eV for H and D, respectively. Thus, MC_DFT gives higher and more negative hydrogen-adsorption energies than the values provided by conventional DFT. By accounting for the H/D isotope effect in a simulated adsorption model, we compared adsorbed H2 to that of its isotopomer, in which deuterium replaces the hydrogen molecule. The H1-H2 bond length predicted by MC_DFT(H) is 0.872 Å, while the D1-D2 distance is 0.850 Å. The diﬀ ;erence arises because of the localized natures of protons and deuterons. We compared the hydrogen-adsorption energies to investigate the H/D isotope effect. The adsorption energy in quantum mechanical treatment of deuteron (quantum D) is less than that for the hydrogen-substituted species, as evidenced by the greater Pt-D1 and Pt-D2 distances. Therefore, the NQE has a significant effect on adsorption energy, and it is vital to include the NQE in any discussion of energetic and geometrical differences between H and D isotopomers. 3.2.2 Consecutive H2, D2 dissociation, and H, D-spillover on Pt/dCNC-2 L Fig. 5 shows simulated PES for H2 and D2 dissociation, and H and D -spillover, obtained by conventional DFT and MC_DFT methods. We previously reported the PES for this reaction on Pt/dCNC-4L, obtained by standard DFT, in our previous work for CO2 hydrogenation [74]. The PES for Pt/dCNC-2L is not significantly different from that for Pt/dCNC-4L. Thus, we focused on our findings for the H-spillover mechanism on Pt/dCNC-2 L, obtained by conventional DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D) methods. From our calculations, we found that all stationary-point configurations have lower energy than for the farthest H2 adsorption on Pt/dCNC-2L (H2---Pt/dCNC-2L). Additionally, the reaction leading to Pt/dCNC-2L, obtained by MC_DFT(H), appears to be the most favorable. The first step of H-spillover reaction is H2 dissociation. Herein, we focus on the hydrogen dissociation step. The H2 bond distances obtained by the different methods are 0.802 Å, 0.872 Å, and 0.850 Å for conventional DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D) methods, respectively. The H2 bonds predicted by MC_DFT are longer than they are for DFT because they take NQE into account. At the transition state for dissociation of H2, DFT gives the HH bond distance as 1.173 Å. The D-D bond distance obtained by MC_DFT(D) increased to 1.188 Å. Additionally, MC_DFT(H/D) predicts greater Pt-H bond distances for both H1 and H2. The activation energy is estimated as 0.06 eV by conventional DFT and 0.01 eV by MC_DFT(D). Interestingly, the activation energy completely vanishes in the MC_QM (H) calculation, which includes the NQE of protons. Researchers previously reported this effect for the H transfer reaction [59] and a zero-point vibrational energy-corrected CBS-QB3 energy profile [88]. In our simulation results, the NQE reduces the activation energy. We also investigated geometrical relaxation induced by including the hydrogen nucleus NQE and investigated the geometrical H/D isotope effect. In summary, we have analyzed H2 dissociation over Pt/dCNC. The MC_DFT method provides lower energies for all stationary-point structures than conventional DFT does. Moreover, smaller activation energies are present in a direct H2-dissociation mechanism. Interestingly, the activation barrier in the MC_DFT(H) simulation vanishes after accounting for NQE. We conclude that the hydrogen molecule dissociates readily over Pt/dCNC. To clarify the mechanism of this step using PES, we analyzed minimum-energy paths (MEPs) in the hydrogen dissociation step for both H and D substitution by using conventional DFT and MC_DFT calculations. From our simulations, MEPs of H and D-species obtained by MC_DFT methods differ from those found by conventional DFT. Accordingly, the NQE is important for both TS and MEP calculations (Fig. 5,6 ). In addition, we analyzed changes in Mulliken charge on the Pt atom and the sum of charges on the hydrogen atoms and neighboring carbon atoms (Fig. 6 ). MEPs for both conventional DFT and MC_DFT(H/D) show increasing negative charges on dissociated hydrogen atoms from the 1st to the 7th image index, for both H and D substituted complexes. Moreover, charges on the neighboring carbon atoms reveal reducing electron density across the series, suggesting that the adjacent carbon atoms generally increase in positive charge across the MEPs, with a dramatic increase between the 3rd and 6th images. Thus, the Pt atom at the cone receives electron density from the C support. The trends in calculated Mulliken charge across the MEPs differ slightly between DFT and MC_DFT methods. From our analyzed results, we see that differences in the nuclear quantum nature of H and D species have an impact on the changes in electronic distribution. Hydrogen spillover has a significant effect on the hydrogen storage capacity. We then focused on H2 dissociation and the first H-atom-spillover mechanism from Pt to the dCNC surface. Here, we discuss the first H-atom spillover to a preferred carbon atom on the CNC surface. The initial configuration for the first hydrogen spillover involves H2 adsorption in D-mode (Fig. 7 ). The relative energies (E rel) of FS1-H2-Disso intermediate are -0.88 eV by conventional DFT, -1.00 eV by MC_DFT(H), and -0.97 eV by MC_DFT(D). At the TS, the bond distance between H1 and H2 lengthens from 2.887 Å (DFT) to 2.922 Å and 2.912 Å by using MC_DFT(H/D), due to the hydrogen nucleus NQE. Similar behavior occurs in the case of the H1-C1 distance. The bond distance given by MC_DFT(H/D) is also longer than that obtained by using conventional DFT. Fig. 5 shows activation energies for the H-spillover mechanism, which are 0.76, 0.71, and 0.72 eV, according to conventional DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D), respectively. The relative energies of FS2-H-spillover are -1.66 eV by conventional DFT, -1.70 eV by MC_DFT(H), and -1.69 eV by MC_DFT(D). The dCNC method predicts that FS2-H-spillover on the Pt supported complex is highly exothermic, confirming that this is a thermodynamically favorable reaction. We measured changes in the Mulliken charge on Pt, H1, and C1 along with the MEPs for H and D species by DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D) (Fig. 7). The charges on Pt and H1 both generally increase across the MEPs. By contrast, both conventional DFT and MC_DFT(H/D) methods show that the C1 atom gains electron density from Pt and H1 at image indexes 3 through 5 in the MC_DFT MEPs. The Mulliken charge trend on C1 is slightly more negative than that predicted by conventional DFT. However, all MEPs show similar overall trends. We thus demonstrate that the NQE of H and D atoms affects the electronic distribution in MEPs. The H/D isotope effect on adsorption and spillover steps over Pt/dCNC shows differences in the quantum nature of hydrogen and deuterium atoms, resulting in a longer H2 bond length than that for D2. In the MC_DFT(D) results, the D1D2 bond distance is 0.850 Å for adsorbed D2, which is shorter than that predicted by MC_DFT(H). At the first transition state, the D1-D2 bond lengthens from 0.850 to 1.188 Å. The Pt-D1 and Pt-D2 bonds are 1.724 and 1.700 Å, respectively (Fig. 4). In the FS1-H2-Disso, TS2-H-Spillover and FS2-H-spillover steps, Pt-D1, Pt-D2, and D1D2 bond lengths are shorter for deuterium than they are for hydrogen. Intermolecular distances increase because of diﬀ ;erences in the localized nature of protonic and deuteronic wavefunctions [89]. Deuterons have twice the mass of protons, and so proton wavefunctions are more delocalized compared to those of a deuteron. Consequently, deuterons have a greater attraction for electron density than protons. The PES predicted by MC_DFT(D) is always higher than that given by MC_DFT(H). Thus, MC_DFT(D) provides higher relative energies for all stationary-point structures. The MC_DFT(D) method provides less stabilization because the NQE for the lighter proton is more significant than it is for the deuteron. In other words, the activation energy of all the elementary steps calculated using MC_DFT(D) is slightly greater than for MC_DFT(H), because of more significant deuteron localization. To see the effect of H/D isotope on dissociation and spillover steps over Pt/dCNC, we have investigated the different reaction kinetics between H and D isotopes obtained by the rate constant via Arrhenius equation. We evaluated kH /kD value at various temperatures (T = 150−450 K) as demonstrated in Table S6. For instance, k1 and k2 of H species are 2.16 and 2.17 times larger than D isotopes for H2 dissociation and H spillover, respectively, at 150 K. At the same manner in various temperatures, we found the rate constant for proton transfer is faster than that for deuterium transfer. These kH /kD value clearly illustrated that the presences of nuclear quantum nature of either proton or deuteron is crucial to understand and analyze the H/D kinetic isotope effects in H2 dissociation and transfer reactions. For the kinetic results, we calculated reaction rate constant and equilibrium constant of all reaction steps over either Pd or Pt/dCNC. Figure S9 illustrates the equilibrium constant of each elementary step at various temperatures obtained by conventional DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D). From our calculations, we found that Ki value for either H2 dissociation or H spillover over Pt/dCNC is greater than 1.00, indicating that the forward reaction is preferably faster than the reverse reaction at all temperatures. Therefore, Pt/dCNC is highly recommended as a material for the hydrogen storage via hydrogen spillover procedure. For the reaction on Pd/dCNC, we found that even through the H spillover on Pd/dCNC is kinetically favorable, the hydrogen dissociation step still has problem due to its preferable reverse reaction (Ki value < 1.00); therefore, the reverse reactions are faster than the forward reaction at all temperatures. In summary, we predicted that either H2 dissociation or H spillover over Pt/dCNC is more thermodynamically and kinetically feasible rather than it is Pd/dCNC. 3.3 Comparison of combined H2/D2-dissociation and H/D-spillover reaction pathways on Pt/dCNC and Pt/dG: curvature effect We studied the combined dissociation and spillover reactions on Pt/dG by conventional DFT and MC_DFT(H/D) methods for comparison with the reaction on Pt/dCNC. We performed a geometrical optimization of Pt adsorbed on dG, as previously described by Rungnim [51]. The Pt atom readily adsorbs on dG, with a binding energy of -6.75 eV, in agreement with theoretical calculations of Pt deposited at a vacancy in a graphene cluster [90,91] and in other periodic models [92], where the binding energy is -6.5 to -7.7 eV [51,91–95]. The Pt-C bond lengths provided by the different methods are 1.948, 1.948, and 1.955 Å, in close agreement with a periodic study that identifies the range 1.93–1.94 Å [92–95]. In this work, we stabilize the edge of the material, we terminated the Pt-dG model by adding hydrogen atoms. Consequently, we have selected an H-terminated model for further study (Fig. 8 ). Herein, we performed a step-by-step investigation of hydrogen spillover on Pt/dG. Fig. 9 shows structures for K- and d-mode hydrogen-adsorption and their related transition states. The hydrogen spillover mechanism starts with K-mode hydrogen adsorption at the Pt catalytic site. Table 2 compares hydrogen adsorption (E ads) and energy barriers (E a) for different materials, obtained by conventional DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D) methods. We found that the adsorption energy of hydrogen on Pt/dG is less than that it is Pt/dCNC, using either conventional DFT or MC_DFT. Figure S8 and Table S3 show that the dCNC structure is more active than the graphene support, with a longer H2 bond distance and greater charge transfer from neighboring C atoms. The TS1-H2-Disso transition state occurs when an H2 molecule dissociates over the Pt/dG surface. The energy barriers obtained by conventional DFT, MC_DFT(H), and MC_DFT(D) are 0.22, 0.14, and 0.16 eV, respectively. FS1-H2-Disso represents D-mode adsorption, which follows the dissociation transition state. Here, the hydrogen-adsorption energy in D-mode over Pt on graphene is smaller than it is on the CNC support because of its shorter H-H bond distance and limited electron transfer from neighboring carbon atoms. Finally, the first H-atom migration begins. Table 2 shows that the activation energy for H-spillover is slightly higher than that for either Pt/CNC or Pd/CNC as a consequence of the effect of curvature in the support [50,51]. Interestingly, Comparing Figs. 5,8& 9, we see that the relative energy of the final state (FS2-H-Spillover) on Pt/dG is much greater than it is for the dCNC support. Overall, the combined H2 dissociation and H-spillover on Pt/dG is thermodynamically unfavorable. Our data reveal that H2 adsorption on the dCNC support is more robust than it is on graphene. The spillover reaction on Pt/dCNC is highly exothermic, suggesting an energetically favorable process. Importantly, the conical shape of CNC materials affects H2-dissociation and H-spillover, which can result in improved performance, as we previously reported [50]. H-spillover from Pt-metal clusters onto C60 currently have activation energies in the range 0.7–1.6 eV [96] similar to that found in our work. Nonetheless, the reaction is endothermic, and thus, thermodynamically unfavorable. Indeed, there are numerous reports of endothermic dissociation and spillover reactions [85–87]. In our work, we found that H2-dissociation and H-spillover from a Pt atom to dCNC are often exothermic, which is an important factor for improvements in hydrogen storage materials. Therefore, Pt/dCNC is a promising new catalytic material for hydrogen storage applications. 4 Conclusions We used MC_DFT to study the hydrogen spillover mechanism on a Pt-atom supported on a carbon nanocone. This approach can take the nuclear quantum effect of protons and deuterons into account. The simulation reveals that the Pt atom acts as an active site for H2 dissociation and H-spillover. Hydrogen dissociation and migration on the dCNC surface are thermodynamically favorable. The reaction is highly exothermic, with a small energy barrier. The curvature on active cone tips provides low-energy sites for hydrogen atoms. In the MC_DFT method results, our calculations illustrate that the NQE for light nuclei, such as protons and deuterons, lowers the relative energy of all stationary-point structures. More importantly, the NQE reduces the activation energy for the associated H-spillover reactions. We also found that the NQE affects MEPs and electronic configurations that occur during reaction. Remarkably, in MC_DFT(H) calculations, the energy barrier to H2 dissociation on Pt/dCNC disappears as a consequence of taking the proton’s NQE into account. Furthermore, the effect of different metal (Pt and Pd) on dCNC surface has been investigated, our significant finding from this work is that the hydrogen dissociation on Pt/dCNC is facile and highly exothermic, while the hydrogen dissociation on Pd/dCNC is dramatically endothermic reaction. Comparing of Pt/dG and Pt/dCNC has also been focused to explain the effect of cone curvature. We found that the curvature has an effect on both H2 dissociation and spillover reactions. The Pt/dG requires higher energy to perform H2 dissociation compared to Pt/dCNC (barrierless) under similar conditions. Moreover, the spillover reaction on Pt/dG is thermodynamically unfavorable, while it is highly favorable for Pt/dCNC. We also discussed the H/D isotope effect on the reaction. We have demonstrated that Pt/dCNC is a new material that shows promise as a catalytic material for highly effective hydrogen storage applications. Our results will be useful for near-future synthesis of Pt/dCNC materials for H2 storage applications. coredata.dc:description: We investigated H-spillover mechanisms on Pt atoms decorating defective carbon nanocones (Pt/dCNC) using the multicomponent B3LYP (MC_B3LYP) method, which can take account of the nuclear quantum effect (NQE) of light nuclei. MC_B3LYP shows reduced relative energies for all stationary-point structures and lower energy barriers to H-spillover reactions. Interestingly, MC_B3LYP calculations reveal that the activation energy for H2 dissociation completely vanishes indicating that H2 molecules dissociate readily on Pt/dCNC. Our crucial finding is that the different metal (Pt and Pd) on dCNC surface has affected the thermodynamic favorability of the hydrogen dissociation process, on Pt/dCNC is facile and highly exothermic, while on Pd/dCNC is dramatically endothermic. Furthermore, comparison of combined dissociation-spillover mechanism on Pt decorated on carbon nanocone (Pt/dCNC) and Pt decorated on graphene (Pt/dG) catalysts have been focused to explain the curvature effect which can facilitate the hydrogen spillover process and provide a highly exothermic reaction, which is more thermodynamically favorable than that of a metal-graphene surface. Our new understanding of this reaction mechanism and the influence of NQEs on electronic properties will be useful for the future development of the spillover mechanism as well as the synthesis of high-performance Pt/dCNC for H2 energy applications.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-doped carbon nanocones as highly efficient catalysts for hydrogen storage: Nuclear quantum effect on hydrogen spillover mechanism
